content.description: Sit-start on the same jugs as "Tall Boy" and use crimps to get you to the fat rail above and to the left. From the rail, it's simple face climbing to a slopey topout.
content.protection: Crash pad and a spotter. Be sure that the area below is free of rock and plant debris as well.
content.location: The starting jugs are below the lip, almost directly below (and slightly to the left) of the dynamite scar. The problem then moves up and to the left of the scar, finishing on a slopey bulge up top.

content.description: Use the same start holds as Thick Neck, Pull up to some nasty holds to nice jugs and a little traverse

Stand start with your left hand a on crimp, right hand undercling and reach for a good edge on the ledge with your left. Gain the thin ledge, use the scrawny tree to help you negotiate the dirty vegetated top out.
content.protection: Pad. Lots of cleaning left to be done on the upper section.
content.location: On the left end of the wall, about the last decent rock before it deteriorates into choss.

content.description: Stand start with left hand on a pinch on the lip of the low overhang, right hand on a high crimp. Get your feet up and reach for the mini ledge with your left. Gain the ledge and head straight up on rails, cracks and pocket
content.protection: Pad; the top out is still dirty, so use caution.
content.location: Start 4 or 5 feet right of Tall Boy, 3 or 4 feet left of Brown Clown, more or less below the long slot high up on the face.

content.description: Stand start with high edges on either side of a brown water streak. Get your feet up then head up on good edges and a pocket.
content.protection: Pad.  The top out is still dirty, so use caution.
content.location: On the right end of the wall. Stand start just to the left of a shallow right facing corner, 3 or 4 feet right of Last Train.

content.description: The K.W. Wall is named after local climber and routesetter Kurtis Watts, who began climbing and testing some of its first problems and sequences.This wall has crimps, slopers, monos, underclings, and just about every other classic limestone feature in between. The slight lip at the bottom of the wall makes for nice sit-starts, after which it transitions into face climbing. Another interesting feature on this wall is the scar from an old dynamite explosion, which has created an incut vertical hold.As for now, the wall is still pretty dirty (especially the bottom below the lip), and much of it is covered by vines and other plants. The top of the wall is easily accessible from its left side, making topouts feasible once it gets cleaned up a bit. This left-side access point should also make it easier for the wall to be cleaned.
